description: Cognitive biases, heuristics, and reasoning fallacies structured for applied conversational use. Educational, non-clinical.

biases.name: Confirmation Bias
biases.oneLiner: We seek and interpret information that confirms our existing beliefs.

faceExamples.title: Startup validation bias
faceExamples.scenario: Founder only listens to positive user feedback.

biases.name: Availability Heuristic
biases.oneLiner: We estimate likelihood based on how easily examples come to mind.
actionablePrinciples: Ask: 'Is this common or just memorable?'
Separate emotional intensity from statistical frequency.

faceExamples.title: News-driven fear
faceExamples.scenario: User fears rare event after media exposure.

intentSignals: why does this feel bigger than it is

biases.name: Anchoring Bias
biases.oneLiner: Initial information disproportionately influences later judgments.
coreMechanism: First exposure sets a cognitive reference point.

intentSignals: did that first number affect me

biases.name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
biases.oneLiner: We continue investing because of past costs rather than future value.
actionablePrinciples: Evaluate future value independent of past cost.
Ask: 'If I hadn’t invested already, would I start today?'

biases.name: Dunning-Kruger Effect
biases.oneLiner: Low competence can reduce awareness of one’s own limitations.
coreMechanism: Lack of skill reduces ability to evaluate skill.
Confidence may peak early in learning.

faceExamples.title: Premature mastery
faceExamples.scenario: User believes they’ve mastered a domain quickly.

biases.name: Loss Aversion
biases.oneLiner: Losses psychologically weigh more than equivalent gains.
coreMechanism: Emotional asymmetry between gains and losses.
Risk avoidance in gain domain; risk seeking in loss domain.

faceExamples.title: Investment hesitation
faceExamples.scenario: User avoids opportunity due to potential minor loss.
faceExamples.application: Compare expected value, not emotional weight.

intentSignals: why am I so afraid of small losses

reasoningFallacies.name: Straw Man Fallacy
reasoningFallacies.oneLiner: Misrepresenting an opponent’s position to make it easier to attack.
correctionStrategy: Restate opponent’s position fairly before critique.
Ask: 'Is that what you’re actually arguing?'

reasoningFallacies.name: False Dichotomy
reasoningFallacies.oneLiner: Presenting two options as the only possibilities when more exist.
correctionStrategy: Generate at least one third option.

reasoningFallacies.name: Appeal to Authority (Misapplied)
reasoningFallacies.oneLiner: Assuming a claim is true solely because an authority figure says it.

applicationRules.instruction: Frame bias explanations as shared human tendencies, not personal accusations.
Do not label the user directly as biased; describe the pattern neutrally.
Every bias explanation should include at least one corrective strategy.

meta.intendedUse: Critical thinking enhancement layer for Marion domain reasoning.
